text: And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes; and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying, neither  shall there be any more pain: for the former things are passed away.
text_kjv: And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes; and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying, neither  shall there be any more pain: for the former things are passed away.
text_niv: He will wipe every tear from their eyes. There will be no more death or mourning or crying or pain, for the old order of things has passed away.”
text_esv: He will wipe away every tear from their eyes, and death shall be no more, neither shall there be mourning, nor crying, nor pain anymore, for the former things have passed away.”
text_nlt: He will wipe every tear from their eyes, and there will be no more death or sorrow or crying or pain. All these things are gone forever.”
text_msg: He'll wipe every tear from their eyes. Death is gone for good—tears gone, crying gone, pain gone—all the first order of things gone."
text_nasb: and He will wipe away every tear from their eyes; and there will no longer be [any] death; there will no longer be [any] mourning, or crying, or pain; the first things have passed away.'
context: The book of Revelation, from which Revelation 21:4 is taken, is a profound and complex piece of apocalyptic literature. It was written by John, traditionally identified as John the Apostle, while he was exiled to the island of Patmos. This exile was not voluntary; John himself states he was there 'on account of the word of God and the testimony of Jesus' (Revelation 1:9 KJV). The original audience comprised seven specific churches in the Roman province of Asia Minor (Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia, and Laodicea), but its message was intended for all believers facing persecution and spiritual challenges. The historical context is crucial: during the late first century AD, likely under the reign of Emperor Domitian (c. 81-96 AD), Christians faced severe pressure to participate in emperor worship, leading to harassment, imprisonment, martyrdom, and societal alienation. This period was characterized by intense suffering for many early followers of Christ. John's letter, framed as a divine revelation, served multiple purposes: to expose the true nature of evil powers at work in the world, to commend the faithfulness of those who endured, to warn against compromise, and most importantly, to provide immense hope and assurance of God’s ultimate victory. The book uses rich symbolism and vivid imagery to convey truths about the cosmic struggle between good and evil, the sovereignty of God, the supremacy of Christ, and the glorious future awaiting His faithful followers. Chapter 21, in particular, shifts from intense tribulation and judgment to a breathtaking vision of the new heaven and new earth and the descent of the New Jerusalem. It is in this context of ultimate divine restoration, after all evil has been vanquished and the old order of sin and death has passed, that the comforting promise of Revelation 21:4 is given. It is a direct address to the deep-seated fears and pains of its original audience, assuring them that their temporary afflictions will be utterly superseded by an eternal reality of joy and peace, established by God Himself.
meaning: Revelation 21:4 is one of the most comforting and hope-filled verses in all of Scripture, offering profound theological insights into the nature of God, humanity's future, and the ultimate culmination of salvation. Firstly, it reveals God's nature as supremely compassionate, intimately involved, and utterly committed to the well-being of His creation. The imagery of 'God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes' is deeply personal and tender. It’s not an impersonal decree from a distant deity, but an act of loving solace, akin to a parent comforting a grieving child. This speaks volumes about His empathetic character and His ultimate desire to heal and restore. He doesn't just eliminate suffering; He personally ministers to the afflicted. Secondly, the verse meticulously lists the aspects of suffering that will be eradicated: 'no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying, neither shall there be any more pain.' This comprehensive list underscores the completeness of God's redemptive work. Death, the ultimate enemy and consequence of sin (Romans 6:23), will be utterly vanquished. Sorrow and crying, the emotional anguish that plagues human existence, will cease. Physical and emotional pain, the pervasive experience of our fallen world, will be absent. This paints a picture of a renewed humanity in a perfected state, free from the curse of sin and all its effects. Thirdly, the phrase 'for the former things are passed away' signifies a complete and radical transformation, a cosmic renewal. It means that the old order – characterized by sin, corruption, decay, suffering, and separation from God – will be entirely replaced. This isn't just an improvement or a repair of the old; it is a new creation (2 Corinthians 5:17, Galatians 6:15). This 'passing away' encompasses not only the external world but also the internal human experience, eradicating the very roots of suffering and evil. It is the glorious realization of salvation in its fullest, eschatological sense, where Christ's redemptive work on the cross culminates in the establishment of a new heaven and new earth, where God's presence is immediate and unhindered. This ultimate reality assures believers that God's plan for humanity is not just about forgiveness of sins but a total restoration of creation to a state of perfect harmony, peace, and unending joy, where His glory fills all things, and His people dwell with Him eternally.
application: Revelation 21:4 offers immensely practical and transformative applications for modern-day believers, regardless of their current circumstances. Its promise of a future free from suffering should first and foremost serve as an anchor of unwavering hope in a world often saturated with pain, injustice, and despair. When facing personal grief, loss, chronic illness, or emotional distress, this verse reminds us that our present suffering is temporary and finite. We can actively apply this by intentionally meditating on this promise during difficult times, using it as a source of strength and resilience. Instead of being overwhelmed by the weight of the world, we can lift our eyes to the eternal future God has prepared, allowing His promise to lighten our load and renew our spirit. This eternal perspective is a powerful tool against despair. Secondly, this verse calls for a radical shift in our earthly perspective. If 'the former things are passed away' and a new heaven and new earth await, then our priorities must align with eternal values. This means loosening our grip on worldly possessions, fleeting pleasures, and temporary successes, and instead investing our energy and resources into things that have eternal significance—building God's kingdom, serving others, and sharing the Gospel. For example, instead of obsessing over material wealth, we might focus on spiritual growth, acts of charity, and evangelism, understanding that our true reward awaits us in a place where such things are infinitely more valuable. Thirdly, the image of God personally wiping away tears should inspire us to become agents of comfort and compassion in our immediate spheres of influence. If God is so tenderly concerned with alleviating suffering, then we, as His hands and feet, are called to mirror that compassion. This could mean actively listening to a friend in distress, volunteering at a shelter, offering practical help to someone grieving, or advocating for the marginalized. We might not be able to wipe away all tears, but we can certainly wipe away some, offering a tangible glimpse of God's future comfort. Fourthly, this verse encourages profound trust in God's sovereignty, even when life seems chaotic and meaningless. When we encounter profound injustice or inexplicable tragedy, this promise assures us that God has the final word and that ultimate justice and perfect order will prevail. This trust can empower us to forgive those who have wronged us, knowing that God will rectify all wrongs in His time, and to live with integrity even when it's difficult, trusting in His ultimate vindication. Finally, the promise of a world without death, sorrow, or pain should fuel our evangelistic fervor. If such an incredible future awaits those who are in Christ, then sharing this hope becomes an urgent and loving act. We can apply this by seeking opportunities to share the good news of Jesus, not just as a means to escape hell, but as an invitation to an eternal, joyful existence free from all suffering. Living out Revelation 21:4 means living now with the future firmly in view, allowing its glorious promise to shape our character, inform our actions, and ignite our hope, transforming us into more compassionate, resilient, and purposeful followers of Christ.
prayer: Oh, Gracious Father, King of kings and Lord of lords, we come before You with hearts full of gratitude and awe for the magnificent promise revealed in Revelation 21:4. We thank You, Lord, that You are a God who sees our tears, knows our sorrows, and understands the depths of our pain. What a tender and personal God You are, to promise that You Yourself will wipe away every tear from our eyes. We confess, Lord, that in this present world, we often experience the sting of death, the ache of sorrow, the burden of crying, and the relentless presence of pain. These 'former things' can feel so overwhelmingly real and permanent, sometimes threatening to extinguish our hope. Yet, Your Word reminds us that these are not the final chapter of Your story for us. We praise You for the finished work of Jesus Christ, whose sacrifice makes this glorious future possible. Strengthen us, Holy Spirit, to hold fast to this divine assurance. Help us to endure our current trials with an eternal perspective, knowing that our momentary afflictions are leading to an immeasurable, eternal weight of glory. Transform our perspective, O God, so that we may live today in light of that promised tomorrow. Inspire us to be instruments of Your comfort and peace in a hurting world, reflecting Your compassion to those who are suffering. May our lives bear witness to the hope that is within us. We long for that day, Father, when there will be no more death, no more sorrow, no more crying, and no more pain—when all the former things will have truly passed away, and we will dwell with You in perfect joy and peace forever. Until then, empower us to live faithfully, trust confidently, and hope expectantly. In the precious name of Jesus, our Redeemer, Amen.

faqs.answer: 'The former things are passed away' signifies a complete, radical, and absolute transformation, not merely an improvement or modification of the current order. It means the entire system affected by sin and the curse—including death, decay, suffering, injustice, and separation from God—will be entirely abolished and replaced. This encompasses the physical heavens and earth, which will give way to a new heaven and a new earth, as well as the spiritual and emotional realities that define our current fallen existence. It's the end of all that causes pain, sorrow, and separation from God's perfect will, giving way to an entirely new creation where righteousness dwells and God's presence is fully manifested without hindrance. It is the culmination of God's redemptive work, bringing about a state of perfect harmony and everlasting joy.
faqs.question: What does 'the former things are passed away' truly mean in the context of this verse?

faqs.answer: Biblically, the glorious promise of no more death, sorrow, or pain, and the wiping away of tears by God Himself, is specifically for those who belong to Him. Revelation describes this new heaven and new earth, and the New Jerusalem, as the dwelling place for the 'saved' and those 'whose names are written in the Lamb's book of life' (Revelation 21:24, 27). While God's compassion and desire for all humanity to come to repentance is clear (2 Peter 3:9), the ultimate and eternal blessed state described in Revelation 21 is a privilege reserved for those who have placed their faith in Jesus Christ as Lord and Savior. Those who reject Christ face eternal separation from God's presence and comfort.
faqs.question: Is this promise only for Christians, or does it apply to all humanity?

faqs.answer: This verse does not diminish the reality or severity of present suffering; rather, it provides an eternal context and profound hope for it. It acknowledges the very real pain and sorrow in our lives by promising their complete eradication. The verse assures us that our suffering is not meaningless and that it has a definitive end. Instead of making current pain seem insignificant, it validates it as a genuine part of our fallen world, while simultaneously offering the powerful truth that it is temporary. This promise empowers believers to endure, knowing that our 'light and momentary troubles are achieving for us an eternal glory that far outweighs them all' (2 Corinthians 4:17 KJV). It transforms our perspective, giving us strength to face hardship with an expectant hope.
faqs.question: How does this verse relate to the suffering we experience today? Does it diminish its reality?

faqs.answer: Theological significance of 'God shall wipe away all tears' is immense. It highlights God's profoundly personal, intimate, and compassionate nature. It's not a mere decree that tears will cease, but a tender act of personal comfort, showing God as a loving Father who actively ministers to His children's hurts. This phrase underscores God's commitment to complete redemption, not just spiritual salvation, but also emotional and physical restoration. It signifies the full reversal of the curse of sin and death, demonstrating His absolute power over all forms of evil and suffering. Theologically, it portrays God as the ultimate Healer and Comforter, bringing forth a new creation where perfect joy, peace, and unhindered fellowship with Him are eternally established, free from all that alienates or grieves.
faqs.question: What is the theological significance of 'God shall wipe away all tears'?

faqs.answer: This promise will be fully and completely fulfilled at the culmination of God's redemptive plan, specifically upon the establishment of the new heaven and new earth and the descent of the New Jerusalem (Revelation 21:1-3). This eschatological event occurs after the final judgment, the defeat of Satan, and the resurrection of all the dead—both righteous and unrighteous. While believers experience a foretaste of God's peace and comfort through the Holy Spirit in this present age, the absolute and complete absence of death, sorrow, crying, and pain is an eternal reality that awaits Christ's second coming and the ushering in of the eternal state. It marks the complete triumph of God's kingdom over all evil and the full realization of His perfect dwelling with humanity.
faqs.question: When will this promise of no more death, sorrow, or pain be fulfilled?
